I've spoken to the locals in town, and it seems like I can trust you with that kind of work.

Take note though, we only pay once goods have arrived at their destination!

If there's one thing I know about as a forewoman, it's that we shouldn't tar all things with the same brush. That applies to guards as well as ships.

Like everyone else in town, they're underpaid. And hunger can make even the most noble of us forget our values.

Still, I'd like to believe that most of them have the town's security at heart.

Name: Marks of the Thaumaturge
Description: Mystical symbols have been engraved on several tree trunks in this part of the forest. The skeleton of a giant auroch rests on the ground surrounded by half-melted candles. Sporadic screams emanate from the treetops but pass as suddenly as they arrive. A sickly odour of decomposition floats in the air.

Dialogs.Content:
Really? With that accent, I had assumed that you had travelled a lot.

I agree, there aren't many, four or five across the continent, but I thought they were better known.

I spent a year at the Academy of Charms in Maliken, but I found the teachers to be too formal for my liking.
I don't know who you are, but prepare to suffer if you are not who you say you are! I am mistress of...

We may be lucky, Leighanna had prepared a puzzle to test the adventurers who were to join her.

Go to Thaumaturge's Bank, this is where you will find out where Leighanna is. The group that was looking for her before you are probably still trying to solve her riddle.
Well, I know that professors don't like to identify the occult sciences as schools of magic. But that's what they are.

Yes, the great fabled folk figure of the seigneury. Also known simply as The Sorcerer.

Over a century ago, so the stories say, a magician stayed in the region who would help those helped him while cursing his adversaries. 

He was, according to some writings, a very powerful cult leader. Unfortunately, he does not seem to have had descendants... or even ancestors. Which makes me doubt that he ever existed at all.

Replies.Content: Do you not think these marks could have been left by an admirer of the myth?

Dialogs.Content:
Ah! there you are... again?

*Deidre stops talking and looks at you.

I mean.. Leigh-gui-who?

Replies.Content: Don't tell me another group has already come looking for her?

Dialogs.Content: Strange and unnatural forces are at work here. Unlike anything related to the Thaumaturge, I don't believe there is anything fraudulent about this.

Replies.Content: I'm looking for Leighanna, she was supposed to meet you.

Dialogs.Content: Hmm. From what I can tell, the symbols on the trees do resemble the signs of the Thaumaturge. And moreover, the person who drew them has mystical knowledge of their own... there are no schools of magic in Kortombe though, which leaves me pensive.

Name: Forest cage
Description: A rudimentary but solid cage hangs from one of the tallest trees in the forest. A closer inspection reveals strange markings carved into some nearby tree trunks.

Dialogs.Content: Didn't Varko tell you? I left to seek aid from Kortombourg, but I never made it. I thought I heard a call for help from the woods but when I went through the treeline to investigate, there was nothing to be seen! And that's when I realised I was trapped.

Or perhaps you were smaller.

*Finn seemed a little frustrated with Sorka's comment, or there's something else going on you don't understand.

Replies.Content: So... what's the story behind this route?

Dialogs.Content: Thank you again for your help.

Replies.Content: Want to chase down the other gremfyrs?

Dialogs.Content: Alright, you do that. I'll just take a minute to rest and nibble on my last slice of bread.
No. There is little to be gained from that now. The wisest thing to do would be to return to Varko. I'm sure he'll be worried. Besides, I want to get out of here.

Replies.Content: Okay. Let me just explore the surroundings and we will leave shortly.

Dialogs.Content:
Many years ago, Sorka and I visited Dunedan in search of the King of the Trees. It was a quest that an old fool living near Gantras had given us.

Anyway, we didn't find the king, but came across...

* Finn frowns and points to a boulder further south.

Under that rock, at low tide, we can reach a tunnel which opens directly into Dunedan. It's vital that you follow me, for if we take one of the many wrong branches of these tunnels, we will be drowned when the tides rise. 

And Sorka? If I say it's to the left, it's to the left! Even if you think you see a golden emperor's medallion between some algae to the right.

Name: Brigands Encampment
Description: This especially rudimentary camp has clearly been erected on a temporary basis. It looks like it would all blow down with a simple gust of wind.

Dialogs.Content:
...

Come back later.

Name: Ruins of Malasette
Description:
Built decades before the Treaty of Maliken, Malasette Castle attracts hundreds of archaeologists, treasure hunters and adventurers each year. 

Unfortunately, the benefits of the footfall for the seigneury are slim, since officially Malasette is located on private land belonging to a warrior-lord from Gantras.

Residents.Name: Cassandra Fonsta

Dialogs.Content: The letter implied that a meeting took place in the valley. Find it, inspect the place, and let's get to the bottom of these no good bandits.

He's one of the five warrior-lords of Gantras. He is therefore one of the foremost influential military leaders in the entirety of Western Pireiria. 

His official home is in Giltanbourg, capital of Gantras.
Good find! The letter indicates the location of a meeting.

Malasette Castle and its grounds belong to the great family, Demalaise - a noble lineage of the Duchy of Gantras. 

The family patriarch therefore owes his allegiance to Gantras, not Wellnear. A fact I'm sure brings him much relief.

You too, eh? While travelling here to my new post, I ran into a few myself. 

Perhaps, we could investigate further? The artless thieves we encountered to the north may know something that could help us end their threat for good.

Yes, I am. Or rather, we are. There are a dozen more trained Gantras swordsmen on standby in our camp over there. 

* Cassandra pauses to think for a moment.

Listen, if you want to excavate the ruins without paying taxes to the Duchy of Gantras, then travel to the duchy and seek an audience with Lord Rafael Demalaise.

I have been made aware that Lord Rafael is looking for adventurers like you for a special assignment. I suspect it would be a mutually beneficial arrangement.
Welcome! You are free to join the excavators and looters rifling through the ruins. Though be warned, you are obliged to hand over a share of whatever you discover to the Duchy of Gantras.

Replies.Content: Gantras? I thought this land was in the seigneury of Wellnear.
Are you going to force me pay a tribute to Gantras?
I encountered thieves on the road.
The thieves' letter mentioned a meeting place...

Residents.Greets: May your mind be sharper than your blade!

Name: The gigantic swarm
Description: Thousands of giant flies swarm the area. Surprisingly, they are not aggressive towards you.

Dialogs.Content: *This creature requires a building with the following characteristics:
*You approach the creature.*
*You notice that flies act and react differently depending on the colours presented to them. You wonder what you could do with this phenomenon.

Name: Kildos Ruins
Description: The Kildos Ruins are, frankly, one of the least interesting places on the entire continent. The ruins consist of a few simple marnite structures that would bore explorer, tourist, and archaeologist alike.

Dialogs.Content:
We're a long way from Darkblade to have to worry about those creatures.

*You explain that you already had to fight them nearby.

If you're telling the truth, that means that there must be a druidic sorcerer controlling them. A nuertogolem would naturally never leave its forest of origin.

Roic's followers have a very strong alliance with the Protectors of the Rose. If someone is creating an army of nuertogolems, we must be ready to protect the common people.

Would you be honourable enough to carry this magical missive letter to the Protectors?

Well then, here we are. I believe we can work together. While I am thrilled by the prospect of visiting that which lies inside the Mists, I must keep a cool head and ask you to build a place where I can be lodged and where I can practice the rites necessary for my rank.

*Palenne hands you a building plan, it seems they had everything already planned out.

With this headquarters in your domain, we can better organize our work.

The risk of threat has surely been amplified. I should probably get used to being less direct in my communications with the guilds.

I've done my research on you, you're from the Mistwalkers. There's no need to try to hide it.

I have a proposal for you which I believe could be beneficial for your group and for Roic's followers.

But first, I would like us to work together on the study of this ruin.
This crystal is not natural, when you touch it, it has no weight. As if it wasn't really here...
As we have already discussed, I will need a place where I can rest and work properly. I will be of no use to you otherwise.

One thing is certain, what I'm looking for isn't here. I've missed something, but I can't put my finger on what it is.

I apologise for my lack of clarity, but I don't know you well enough to give you more details.

Replies.Content: So, this place is of no interest?

Dialogs.Content: Can I help you?

Replies.Content: Are you ready to join us?
Do you know anything about the nuertogolems?
Your missive made quite the impression in Gantras...

Dialogs.Content:
Not during the day, but I wouldn't come here at night. I don't know what happened here, but spirits haunt the place, that's for sure.

I'll have to ask the high council for help in purifying the place.

Name: Barracks
Description: The majority of Kortombe militiamen are hunters and peasants who have volunteered to patrol a few hours a week. Half a dozen trained soldiers form the permanent guard.

Dialogs.Content: Make haste. The situation is likely to escalate quickly.

No...

*Tarul makes sure he and you are alone.*

You warned me of what is happening in Wellnear, I believe that all the players in the political sphere are beginning to feel that something is happening.

With the Corvus around, the nervousness is at its highest.

But, as surprising as it may seem, that's not even what I want to ask you today.

I know you've only just arrived in town, but if you want to make yourself useful, I have a little job for you.

The village folk have been reporting property stolen from their homes over the last few days. Oddly, they have all been items of little monetary value. 

At first I thought it was just idle minds busying themselves and distracting themselves with some drama. But now a dozen houses have reported being burgled. 

My guards are not the most delicate of investigators. If I put them on a case like this, it will only stir up more drama. If you could investigate subtly, I would appreciate it.

Replies.Content: Thank you for the offer, but I'm looking for something a little more entertaining.

Dialogs.Content:
Agreed. Somebody is sending them to Kortombe, I'm sure of it. I know not who and I know not why. Though I suspect the witch is merely a pretext. 

I should talk to Badouk Brank, for he knows mercenaries' circles well. 

Say, you know Leonidas, don't you? I'm not fooled, your Lantern is a real giveaway. Badouk Brank was hired by Leonidas, I believe. If you ever find Badouk, I have a few words to say to him.

In addition, I've promised to deliver an artefact to Leonidas for study. You could kill two birds with one stone. Would that interest you?

Replies.Content: I'll get my gear and I'll return for this later.

Dialogs.Content: Thank you, but no thank you. Your collaboration was much appreciated, but I can handle this alone.

Well, I have a good friend who is based at the Diadem Manor and who planned to investigate the forest of Malarcane for me.

But...

The situation in Kortombe becomes far too dangerous for her, due to her... origins. I have to find a way to get her away from the lordship.
Welcome to Kortombourg! Respect the law and your stay in the barony will be most pleasant. Let me introduce myself, Sir Tarul Verdant, Protector of Kortombe.

Replies.Content: What is there to do in Kortombourg?
Do you need my help again?
You seem troubled. Can I help you?
You wanted to talk to me?

Dialogs.Content: So be it. But act quickly, the situation could quickly become explosive.

I am afraid I do, yes. My guards have informed me of the arrival of several groups of mercenaries in Kortombe.

I have no idea how such silly rumours get started, but folk have got it in their heads that there is a witch up to mischief in Bonarcane Forest. I thought with time, the fuss would stop and the gossip would fade away, but I was wrong. 

Wealthy Merchants with more silver than sense have called in mercenaries from neighbouring seigneuries. 

Leona, a trapper, confirmed the location of a camp for these supposed witch hunters. I need someone I can trust to stop them before they hurt or kill someone.

Replies.Content: Okay. I'm busy right now, but I'll be back.

Dialogs.Content: My fears have come true. Several of these supposed witch hunters got drunk and clashed in the village. I must deal with this, will you accompany me? Damn fools can't handle their liquor.

Replies.Content: I'll join you in a moment, I must finish a couple of things first.
I shall take up arms and walk by your side.

Dialogs.Content:
Some, yes. I'm mostly thinking of the Grandmoons and the Filouderiens. They live in the Bonarcane and Caledorn forests, respectively.

If you are bored, you can always visit the Filouderiens. They may need help. As for the Grandmoons, they are normally able to solve their problems just fine on their own.

The only animals that present much of a danger around here are the vargrs. It's debatable if you can call the critters "animals" but the gremfyrs also worry some people. Not me though, the gremfyrs will only attack if they are in a state of rage or fear. Plus, their presence keeps ogres and other barbaroids at bay. 

If you want to know more about the region's predators, you should visit Raven Manor and speak with the baroness's son.

There are a few dozen brigands who rage and roam in the seigneury. They are not extremely dangerous though entering open conflict with them would require more resources than I have at my disposal. Instead, we have an uneasy compromise. I control their numbers, make sure they do not kill anyone, and ensure that they do not harm commerce.

The look on your face suggests you think that is lazy. It is more a question of necessity and pragmatism. Daily patrols outside of Kortombourg would require heavy taxation on distant citizens and itinerant merchants. That is to say, on those who would prefer to ensure their own protection anyway.
Pity. If you change your mind, you know where to find me.

*For what seems to be the first time since you met him, Tarul Verdant relaxes and bursts out laughing.

Apologies for my uncouthness! Professor Lightmind would be quite angry with me if he had heard me use that term. For me, it means all the uncivilized humanoids who roam the territory of Pireiria. Academicians prefer the term goblinoids, but it's of little importance to me.

Protector, and proud to be so. That means I oversee the day-to-day direction of the guards, both those of Kotombourg village and those of the castle. I also train militiamen, discuss questions of security with my counterparts across the realm, and administer more-or-less everything related to the borders of the barony. 

It is quite the responsibility, but one I accept wholeheartedly.
It's always better to be well equipped.

No...

*Tarul makes sure he and you are alone.*

We know something happened in Wellnear but we don't know exactly what yet. Rumors of high treason, making my whole team nervous.

Badouk is with you, so I imagine you know something, I remember he has a connection with the lord.

But, as surprising as it may seem, that's not even what I want to ask you today.
I know you investigated me. As a man of duty, I cannot hold it against you. Though nor do I feel obliged to share my actions or lack thereof to you. At least not for the moment.

Well there you go, I ran into Corrin Fortvaillant's father. He tells me that his son was lodged with you in a domain in the clouds. Guess he misunderstood the situation, but that's exactly what I need for Leighanna.

Besides, I have a mission for her that would require an armed group. She already knows the details, are you interested?

Replies.Content: Yes, where can I find this person?

Dialogs.Content:
For you, yes. I have a special mission that I would like to entrust to someone other than my militiamen. I have a prisoner who has seen sense and has agreed to exchange information for a shorter prison sentence.

Escort him to a place called Longuemire, and he'll show you where the robbers' lair is.

Replies.Content: I have no space to bring him with me right now.

Dialogs.Content: Woah there! You are more skilful than you look. I should have a mission or two for you very soon.

*By chance, you come across Myrtille who is also out on patrol.

I'm impressed. I hope that our future collaborations will be just as profitable.
Come back to me when you know. We all know the dangers of misinformed witch hunts.
If I understand you correctly, you're implying that you have reached the maximum number of companions. That is a strange concept indeed. I'll never understand outsiders.
Hmm... yes, actually. I think I do. A hermit, living in the forest of either Bonarcane or Malarcane. Do you think she's the witch?

Replies.Content: Perhaps. I do not yet have enough information to know for sure.

Dialogs.Content: Don't delay for long, the gremfyr threat is spreading day by day.

There aren't usually so many gremfyrs roaming Kortombe. They live in the mountains and hide in caves.

I suspect that a leader has emerged from their ranks who is forcing them to venture closer to the town. We must find and fight this creature. 

If you are up for the challenge, venture into the cave to the northeast, on the other side of the forest.

One of Korllights scribes thinks a magical being connected to the gremfyr's aquatic rituals may be the source of our problems.

Replies.Content: That sounds dangerous, I will do it later.

Dialogs.Content: * Myrtille explains that the militia posts missions and the schedule of their training on a bulletin board located in front of the barracks. *

More and more gremfyrs are being reported in the vicinity of Kortombourg. They are not normally aggressive creatures, but they scare travellers and attack animals.

I must admit that I have a little remorse for giving you this contract, but I need you to go to the forest east of here and eliminate some of the sorry little creatures.

You will, of course, be rewarded for your efforts.

Replies.Content: Perfect. Now this is a mission for me.
I can't do that right now.

Dialogs.Content:
As you wish. I suppose eventually I'll be able to spare some militiamen who can take care of it. 

Let's just hope that until then there aren't any more dead children found in the woods, eh?
When the call to discover the truth becomes too loud, return to me.
Go to the infirmary if you have bandages and potions to dispose of, we tend to consume a lot of them during missions.

I must confide in you. Do you not also find it peculiar that Tarul Verdant seems unconcerned with rumours of witches in the seigneury?

Our dear Protector, the future baron, is planning something. And I, for one, think it's time to take an interest. The seigneurial family must be warned if a threat could befall them. 

Were we to investigate him, I have a few friends who could keep an eye on him and warn you if he grows suspicious. All this being totally hypothetical, of course.

Replies.Content: I don't have time to worry about this.
That is suspicious. I'm willing to help you.

Dialogs.Content: I'm the quartermaster of the barracks. Basically, that means I line up the recruits and bring the wine for the veterans.

Replies.Content: Do you need anything at the barracks?
I can handle a few weapons, but I lack finesse. Do you have time to train me?
Where do the gremfyrs come from?
Psst, over here! Be careful that Sir Verdant doesn't notice you.
Do you know someone named Leighanna?

Dialogs.Content:
Frankly, training would-be adventurers is not my job. Then again, I doubt you are the usual type who spends their days resting at The Queen's Fianc.

It is therefore my duty to ensure that your recklessness does not endanger anyone. Including yourself.

In addition, if you become a skilled warrior, you may lighten the load for the militia.

Let's train in the alley.

Replies.Content: Maybe I'm not skilled enough to train with you after all. I'll be back when I'm up to the task.

Name: Kortombourg Square
Description:
[D] Wooden benches and tables have been placed in the pleasant central square of Kortombourg. In good weather, families and seniors come to socialise, stroll, and pass the hours. Some traders have set up kiosks there to sell food, drink and alcohol to those who come to while away the hours.

[N]At night, the central square of Kortombourg is almost entirely deserted. Some garbage discarded by disrespectful citizens blows in little circles in the wind. From time to time, some teenagers come to sit on one of the benches to chat quietly or to drink a few bottles out of sight of their parents.

Dialogs.Content:
Mylena, like most respectable citizens of Kortombourg, quietly returns home after sunset. I don't mean to suggest that those who roam at night have something to hide, but...

Anyway! If you want my opinion, you should go and rest at The Queen's Fianc and return at a more sociable hour.
What are you up to lingering in the town square at this time of night? Ah, don't worry. There is no curfew, you can do as you please.

Residents.Name: Mylena Imratti

Dialogs.Content: Indeed. My friend Julien Desgriffes left yesterday morning for the Woods of the Forgotten. I worry for his safety. I suspect he was planning to come back with a few good logs to build a treehouse for his kids. If you could visit those woods and search for him, I would feel reassured.

Replies.Content: I think I need a rest first.
I'll get ready to leave now.

Dialogs.Content:
Indeed I do. I am a popular lady, after all. This time, it's Alphonsine Bluebonnet. She can't afford to buy stones directly from the quarry, but she needs them to complete her wall.

While I think about it, I've been in touch with Gemma, Julien's wife. She is worried, but thanks you for your help.

Replies.Content: I have a bad back. I think I'll find some different work for the moment.
Tell me where Alphonsine is and I'll join her.

Dialogs.Content:
Yes! I have a friend who needs marsh pepper to prepare a banquet. Please collect 500 specimens of every variety... Ha! Your face! I'm joking, of course. 

Truly, thank you for your help. I advise you visit the town and chat with its residents. Some will surely need your help. Perhaps you should start at the Queen's Fianc or Kortombourg Market.
I was looking forward to this package. Thank you!
As you wish, but I believe that you should return to see him anyway. And it really isn't heavy.

No, but I just received an interesting letter from my friend Ulrick at the Tower Construction Site. Head back to the site and earn his trust before he tells his story to the whole world! 

He also mentioned a strange but peculiar character who came to his aid at the Troll Bridge, which leads me to believe you may have already made his acquaintance.

Most people will have to learn to trust you before telling you about their troubles and needs. Once you have succeeded in gaining the confidence of a few influential citizens, the others may confide more easily too. Then, by rendering them services, you can strengthen those bonds of trust.

Unfortunately, as in all communities, there are unsavoury individuals in Kortombourg. If that is the sort of company you seek, well I suspect they will be more talkative with you if you behave badly in town. Though I count on you to always respect propriety and the law.

One final point, we live in a fairly united lordship, but there are certain divisions. It is therefore possible that certain groups will listen to you only if you have already established contact with them. 

For example, soldiers may not pay you much heed if you can bake a loaf of bread, but should they discover you are skilled with a blade, their respect will be yours.

Baroness Relene is in charge of Kortombe. She oversees everything that happens and deals with trade relations with the leaders of the capital and the other territories of Pireiria.

Her daughter, Celeste, is the burgomaster and my boss. She mainly takes care of the needs of the Kortombourgers. Her team collects taxes, distributes public funds and permits, and helps in the all-too-regular event of a disaster.

Cedric Duverger Kortombe is her half-brother and the forest master. He ensures compliance with rules on hunting and forestry, and manages relations with citizens who live outside of the village. His father Charles is the baroness's husband and an important merchant.

Then there is the knight, Tarul Verdant, who carries the title of Protector. He deals with security and military training. He is also the master-of-arms of the ruling family.

A bad back, eh? It looks alright to me. I understand that helping ordinary people may seem boring for someone with a more adventurous spirit, but it's a good way to gain renown. Legends aren't built overnight you know!

Ah, it's a secret!

Though I did just notice a note for you in the package. Leonidas has asked me to send you to the ruins in the hills.

Would you like to go now?

Replies.Content: Yes, the tales of Leonidas intrigue me.

Dialogs.Content: I have a lot of work on at the  moment, but I guess I could spare a few minutes to answer your questions. Call it Kortombourg hospitality!

Replies.Content: Could other people provide me with work?

Dialogs.Content: As you wish, but it would have allowed you to get to know the seigniory better.
My friend Geraldine left with a team of harvesters to collect chinvre. It is not heroic work, nor well paying, but it will allow you to get to know the locals and their daily lives.

Replies.Content: That isn't nearly heroic enough for me.

Dialogs.Content:
Ha! Errm, no, outsider. As much as I like it here, I do not sleep in Kortombourg Square.

Like most citizens, I return home at the end of the day. As you will see, Kortombe is a much quieter place at night.

Though I should warn you, there are those who prefer the discretion of the night whom you will only find after the setting of the sun. And indeed there are those who barely seem to rest, day-or-night.

If you need to see someone who has gone to bed, you will have to wait until they wake before talking to them. It's up to you to determine what to do while you wait. The Queen's Fianc offers beds for those who have no home nearby.

If you're implying that I'm having some sort of affair with him, that is none of your concern! How dare you insult my honour!

* Mylena gives you a look full of reproach before bursting into a powerful laugh.

Don't worry! I understood your question. But no, I don't come from the same place as you two...

* Mylena gives you a knowing wink.

Besides, I've received a package for him... an object related to his Mist Lantern. Would you mind bringing it to him?

Replies.Content: I don't have time to take care of it.
As you wish, Mylena. I'll leave immediately.

Dialogs.Content: I wish you a warm welcome to Kortombourg! A fine village in a fine area of the world! And, if I may say so myself, you have stumbled upon one of the village's most useful and informed residents... me!

Replies.Content: I have a few questions for you about how things work around here.
You said you had a job for me?
I'm still looking for work, can you help me?
Do you have other friends in need of my help?
Do you have another task for me?
Do you have any more friends-in-need for me?
You seem to know Leonidas rather well...

Dialogs.Content: Alright, just don't sleep in too late. He may be hurt and alone.
I understand. If you change your mind, come back to me. You never know where simple work could lead.

Usually, I don't take care of providing work for passing adventurers. Then again, seeing as it was old Leonidas who sent you...

*Mylena gives you a cheeky wink.

Let's start with something simple, I have a letter which must be given to a friend living somewhere on the plain of Kortombe. Though if you feel like it, you could explore the village of Kortombourg before delivering it.

Replies.Content: I don't really want to be a postman.

Dialogs.Content: I am one of the scribes working for the burgomaster. A burgomaster? It's similar to a mayor. Anyway, I take care of welcoming travellers and traders, and I help citizens fill out all their official documentation. I am also the person to meet to discuss permits and property rights.

Residents.Greets: Hey, you! Come closer! It's surely me you seek.

Name: Captain Sternakovic's Jewellers
Description: Like several buildings in Thorbourg, the main structure of the jewellers was built from the wreck of an old boat. The interior of the store is well lit, with the least expensive jewellery placed on luxurious pedestals and mannequins. The most valuable pieces are tucked away inside locked glass and steel cages.

Residents.Name: Anya Sternakovic

Dialogs.Content: I imagine so, otherwise no one would want it.

Welcome to the store! Our jewellers was founded by mother ten years ago. We don't make jewellery, but we sell those designed by the students of Thormalek Academy. We also have a small workshop that enables us to repair them for you, should you require it.

Pensive, huh? That's about right. We have to produce a new jewellery collection for an exhibition in the capital. And, yes, I mean Maliken!

I'm looking for something that will serve as background for the jewellery. Something reminiscent of the wild lands of the continent. My idea was to use leather, but I don't have a craftsman specialised in leatherwork.

Residents.Greets: It costs nothing to admire our jewellery!

Name: South bank of Moulanasul
Description: A large boulder juts out into Titan Lake, making it possible to moor a ship.

Name: Dirontol Hop House
Description: Recognized throughout western Pireiria, the hops produced in Dirontol have a slight taste of lemon and mango. Over thirty farmers work in the fields while the brewery itself has more than ten full-time employees.

Dialogs.Content:
We've been cleaning our large odiemel fermenter. Our last beer used a special pungent hop imported from Jawana.

Here's a fascinating fact for you, the Great Dyery of Enorwen uses the dregs, the residue from fermentation of this beer, to make certain dyes.

However, I have a problem. No captain will embark with my cargo of dregs.

I'm far too busy with my hops to know what's going on day-to-day. As you probably know, this is an important port for Pireiria. The main activities, therefore, revolve around trade, alcohol, shipbuilding, fishing and piracy.

The smell of dregs attracts strange creatures living in the Gulf of Enorwen.

The last crew were slaughtered trying to protect the boat.
Ah! You're truly not from here. "Jon Thorval" is the honorary title given to our counts in honour of one of the founding captains of our port.

I have to say, yes, I'd love you to. This suckhops attack, it's left me feeling shaken and a little scared.

There's no point complaining directly to Jon Thorval. If the Pringdan family is involved, we won't be getting any help from the authorities.

Seeing as the attack comes from the islands, I suspect an investigation of the city port would be a savvy starting point.

That's what I was afraid of. Trade wars can be terrible. I won't make accusations without proof, but if someone is targeting the hop fields near Thorval, the attack is surely coming from one of the islands.

There are other hop houses, the largest being Pringdan.
My apologies! I'm so accustomed to talking to fellow brew freaks that I forget that not everyone knows our specialized language. An ohl is essentially a high fermentation beer.

Hmm. That name means something to me, yes. He's a hunter who lives south of the city.

I know he's a master trainer of sandvargrs, a terrible breed found only in the desert.

Why?

*You explain to Galena that you have a lead pointing towards Vorf.

I don't know him well enough to say if it's possible, you're going to have to investigate. But I warn you, a pack protects him.

Replies.Content: Then I too will not go alone.

Dialogs.Content: Welcome to Dirontol!

Replies.Content: Do you want me to investigate?

Dialogs.Content:
Ha! Always! Thorbourg is one of the busiest ports on the continent, and if there's one thing sailors love, it's beer! Well, and sailing.

At the inn, you'll find several of our varieties of beer. I recommend the Oasthouse Pale Craft of Thorval, better known as OPCT. It's a little bitter, so it's not for the faint of heart, but it's undoubtedly our best! Oh and try the Royal Black Ohl too, it's most excellent.

I realise historically this term was reserved for civilians paid by the state to hamper enemy fleets in war. But since naval wars are thankfully rather rare these days, the Jon Thorvals make sure to keep privateers happy by giving them security and espionage missions.

Essentially, they're captains hired by the county to fight crime on the high seas. They're rather less effective on dry land.

If you're familiar with the area, you'll certainly appreciate the large amount of cultivars found on the land. Please feel free to visit the brewery and the hop cultivation fields. However, if you're looking to purchase our beers and related products, you'll have to go to the central market in Thorbourg.

Replies.Content: Is the beer market doing well?
What can you tell me about Thorval and Thorbourg?

Dialogs.Content: You suggest that Galena deliver her dregs by road instead of using a boat. You must take the cargo to the Great Dyery of Enorwen. You hope that the path does not pass too close to the sea.

I'm fine, but my plant cultures are another story. Is there no hope for my hops?

A new pest that I've never seen before is relentlessly attacking my crops.

*Galena shows you a small, unnatural-looking insect.

I called them suckhops...

Could you help me with my infestation?

Technically, I don't think we can call them pirates. But there are several rogue captains who will joyfully steal cargo from other ships. Others disrupt their rivals' business deals, burn down their warehouses, assault their competitors' employees... I'm sure you know the type. 

In extremely rare cases, some captains attack and ransack ships on the open sea. Though privateers have been very effective in combating this kind of high seas barbarism.

Name: The Ancestor
Description: The Ancestor is an old tree over 400 years old which is almost 10 meters high. Its dry, grey bark gives the impression that it's dead, but a few leaves appear each spring. Numerous rumours, particularly concerning corpses and treasures buried at its foot, are constantly circulating in the barony.

Dialogs.Content:
The holiday exists to remind everyone that death is an integral part of the natural cycle of life. Instead of through traditional education, the people of the Circle of the Great Tree decided to help people understand this notion through a festival.

Today, many nobles use the festival as an excuse for lavish banquets and other frivolities. But at its core, the festival serves its purpose of making death less frightening among the people.

I am, but do not think I am only here for these matters of the Gift. I watch the tree known as the Ancestor.

We wonder if it is corrupt like other parts of the continent. The last thing the Circle wants to deal with is a 400-year-old undead tree.

Haha! Did you think it would be a simple stroll?

I have a clue for you, some of these places are only discoverable at night. Others, even rarer, can be found solely at dawn or dusk. And to complicate matters further, some will only appear if Mother Nature is in a favourable temperament... you know... if it's raining or not.

And, of course, these plants can die in cities or caves too. Good luck!

Replies.Content: You don't have anything more specific?

Dialogs.Content: Maratatinus gives many small gifts at the festivals he organizes. He is interested in trading simple emblems for a higher quality one.
We are the keepers of the energy of life. All are under its influence, those of nature and those who claim to be civilized.

Replies.Content: Will I be invited to join?

Dialogs.Content:
Hail! Hail!

I see that you know a little of our customs, even though you do not come from this region.

Replies.Content: What can you tell me about the Somberseason?
I can't find any more places for the rituals...

Dialogs.Content:
Interesting. Well, you do have "the Gift" after all. Ha! Sorry, but the peasants who go crazy for a minor healing spell make me laugh. 

Not all Circle members are trained combatants, the majority of our members take care of forest animals and plants. I know Rackham is setting up a "control" team for all of the corrupted ruins in the area. 

Are you interested in becoming part of that team?

The Sanctuary of Eternity is in Norkantas. This forest is one of the most complex biomes on the continent! Even an experienced adventurer can get lost there in a matter of moments.

However, the druids have created a passage for you to follow. All that's left for you to do is explore the perimeter of the forest to find the entrance to the secret trail.

Ahaha! Hail the Somberseason!

Well, here are the details. The Ancestor, that big tree behind us, produces acorns that can be enchanted by a ritual we perform in the spring. During the Somberseason, we collect the acorns and task adventurers to find sentient plants that have just died.

By planting the acorns near the remains, you will ensure an easier passage to death and protect them from corruption. It is also said that a part of the person's soul will stay close to the future trees that grow from the acorns.

Oh yes. If the ritual is done well, a Life Pearl will materialize. You must bring me these pearls. I even have gifts for you in return!

Replies.Content: Fancy coloured drinks and fancy dress? I think I'll just take the tavern option, thanks.

Dialogs.Content: Awww, are you as scared as Sorka?
You surprise me. I thought mysterious rituals and rare rewards were more your nature.
You are a fascinating individual... like everyone who walks this world.

Replies.Content: The Circle of the Great Tree?

Dialogs.Content:
Most locals disguise themselves as the dead and inevitably end up, in full costume, at the local inns drinking strange coloured alcohols.

But... I suspect that for adventurers like you, an ancient ritual of the Circle of the Great Tree would be more appropriate.

Interested?

Perfect. The famous Living Ruins certainly deserve a little more study. I believe that the walking dead are not the only beings that haunt the place. The behaviour of the apparitions should be studied closely.

If you can do this for me, I'll introduce you to the guild.

Replies.Content: I have to get ready, but I'll be back.

Dialogs.Content:
Not yet. Your path has not quite reached that destination. 

You have potential, but I sense other energies in you that I do not understand. I shall consult my superiors.

I can tell you have some ability to manipulate energies. You're not a simple peasant, are you?

To gain a greater understanding, you must relinquish your need for control. If you want to be invited to the Circle, you will have to become one with the flow of energy, not insist on being its master.

Are you after a map with markers?! That would break the magic of the event a bit, eh?

I have one last clue for you. Somberseason gives residents a sense of nostalgia, sometimes, if you listen to them well, you might find some clues that will help you.

Hail the Somberseason!

Ahh, you were the one who studied the creeping crawling living dead for Sorka, right? I knew that she wouldn't do it herself, I suspect she fears the spirit world. She probably told you I was a necromancer! Ha! She doesn't understand anything about our guild. All she wants is action.

But yes, to answer your question, the Living Ruins is one of those corrupt places.

Replies.Content: I would like to help fight corruption.

Name: Bay of Warmth
Description: Some picturesque homes have been built around a natural bay. Many small boats, too small to navigate an ocean, rock gently in the waters.

Name: Yolasula's Abode
Description: A small, unconventional house built of mixed materials is located on the highest hill in the area. There is a huge telescope stationed on the roof.

Dialogs.Content: Yolasula often needs Minoris Catalyst for her experiments with explosive golems. She exchanges them for better quality catalysts.

As I thought was clear by my wrinkles, I was not born yesterday...

But fine, keep your secrets if you will. I have golems to whip up!

Now that you know the fundamentals of the power of fire, you can help me with the wood golems.

They went north, bypassing the forest to the east.

Remember, to defeat the golems you will need to use the fire evocation I taught you!
They're going to ask me for tons of reports again.

Replies.Content: I'm ready to learn the basics of wind evocation.
I'm ready to learn the basics of water evocation.
Can you tell me more about the Arcanists?

Dialogs.Content:
The Arcanists Guild is a group of scholars who study magic in all its forms. I myself am a member of the guild.

As you may have observed, they love anything written on parchment. Forms, paperwork, surveys, you name it. 

For my part, I'm more of the "practical work" type. I try to sell them the idea that improvisation is the greatest catalyst to discovery. Sadly, most ears are deaf to my ideas. 

Your mastery of elemental magic seems particularly good to me. I think it would be appropriate to officially introduce yourself to the guild.

And, believe it or not, we'll need to fill out a form of introduction!

Replies.Content: By your description, I'd have been more surprised if we didn't have to.

Dialogs.Content:
I wouldn't say no. I'll make a start on the incident forms, and pray you deal with them before I have to fill in the accidental death and mutilation forms.

Ah, no, wait. The task will require an evocator.

*Yolasula looks at your Lantern.

Oh, what? Fascinating. Is that your channelizer? I've never seen one like that, what kind of Arcanist are you?

Brilliant! One less report for me!

To fight the next golem, you are going to have to become one with the wind... as light as a feather but as powerful as a hurricane.

The Arcanists! Hang on... who in the heavens are you? I didn't see you coming. Did nobody ever teach you to knock?

In any case, you've arrived at a bad time. One of my experiments has just gone wrong. Very wrong.

A few days ago, I would have told you no. Yesterday, however, I was a little overambitious in my attempt to reproduce models of golemic construction from an old grimoire of mine. And to my surprise, delight, and horror the creatures came to life.

These unfinished creatures had no instructions and no off-switches. They ran around like headless chickens before disappearing into the wilds.

They have to be destroyed before they hurt someone or worse yet... someone forces me to fill out a ton of reports accounting for what happened!
Oh no! How rude! And just think of all the reports I'll have to write!

If you wish, I can help you to complete the form of introduction. I'm going to have to indicate that I've taught you the basics of three things, but we won't go into details.

Next, you will have to reach the Cave of Knowledge which is hidden behind a waterfall in Vizek Point.

The chrono-golems have no visible weakness. Fortunately, the wind isn't visible. 

The power of the wind disrupts their gears, damaging their complex mechanics. 

They were heading east last time I saw them.

That pleases me greatly. If you get this done, then my wayward experiments might go completely unnoticed. Maybe soon I'll have no reports to write at all. 

The last type of golem I activated was a stone golem. You must master the basics of water evocation if you are to stand a chance against its solid hide.

Hurmm, they do say that a problem shared is a problem halved. I guess you've just volunteered to be the guinea pig for my latest theory.

For a long time, I've been trying to understand what animates certain magical creatures composed of inert materials. It is not yet a science well-understood by the Arcanists, so they're very happy to help me in my research.

The general term for such creatures is "golem".

Replies.Content: Fascinating! Are there any golems around?

Dialogs.Content:
The weakness of stone golems is water. 

Don't look so surprised. Many a great cliff and mountain has fallen to water; seeping through the cracks, freezing, and cracking its stony foe from the inside.

Talking of stony foes, the golems you're looking for went southeast.

Let's find these golems before the Arcanists discover what I've done!

Each type of golem is vulnerable to an element. Without mastering the art of evocation, you will be useless to me. I can try to teach you the basics of fire. If you're receptive to my lessons, we can get started with the wood golems.

Replies.Content: I'm ready to become a fire starter. Let's learn.
Hmmm... evocation... fire... golems... go fend for yourself...

Name: Hammer Relay
Description: The Hammer Relay is undeniably rustic, yet all who come across it agree that that is part of its charm. It has a few beds to rent and filling meals that are almost hot. Its walls have been designed in stones of many colours. Both lovers of the visual arts and adventurers looking to save some money can't expect much better in this area of Ordval.

Dialogs.Content: And where are you passing through, to?
Oh not far then. Just keep following the rising sun to the east, friend.

Then head northwest. You'll pass the Corinna Inn then the Anvil Relay which my brother administers. After that, you'll need to bypass the Tarasquan in the north. There's not a relay, tavern, or inn in that whole region, so be prepared to camp.
Classic! What are you adventurers like? Eh? I've never heard of anything like that in the east, but my brother at the Anvil Relay has mentioned a ruin in the north of the plain.

Wow, you have a long journey ahead of you if you're to make it to Gantras. Once you arrive at the Corinna Inn, you'll need to head north to the Biggoat Relay. 

That, of course, will be the easy part. The rest of the trip will be much trickier due to the complete absence of relays and inns in the forests of Kantas.

Avoid Corinna Forest at all costs. In addition to being a veritable labyrinth, it's populated by dangerous creatures. 

Fortunately for the rest of us, they rarely leave the confines of the forest.

[D]Good day, hope you're enjoying the weather! Can I help you?

[N]Good evening, would you like a room for the night?

Replies.Content: I'm hoping to explore the Hammery Plain.

Dialogs.Content: Well you've come to the right place to begin your exploration. You could also check in at the Corinna Inn further west if you're looking for another cosy spot to lay your head.

Replies.Content: Are there ruins or ancient places?

Dialogs.Content: Then you, my friend, are lost. Get yourself to Kortombourg and then head south.
[d] Everywhere, but not there
[D] I am the test girl NPC
[D] This is a dialogue test.
[D] Hello, I am Cloud, screenwriter and designate at Virtys.
[D] Of course, I write the script and all the texts.
[D] A super cool company with its head office in Quebec.

Name: Forsec Mine
Description: Still considered to be one of the most important feros mines in Ordval, the Forsec Mine employs more than 150 workers, coming from Kortombe and the neighbouring seigneuries. Recent excavations have revealed that there is also a vein of eliendel and odiemel in the vicinity.

Dialogs.Content:
Huurgh. I hope I won't catch you planting acorns in my mine!

Go tell that to the people who live on the mountaintop instead! We can hear them from here every night at sunset, just when we're trying to get some bloomin' sleep!
I am the principal supervisor of the miners and the representative of Anissa Forsec when she is not here herself.

Thanks for asking! We're waiting for a shipment from the seigneury of Wellnear, but it seems that the caravan is late. If you are going that way anytime soon, you would be kind to inquire with those responsible for the central market. They could tell you what is delaying delivery.

That's what I said. She retains the rights to the mine which was founded by her ancestors a few generations back. She's one of the most important employers of the seigneury. You are not from around here, are you?

Name: Raonis Blast Furnace
Description: The Raonis Blast Furnace is a private installation, though the local metal craftsman of Gantras are free to use it. Some travellers may also carry out work there, though they must have previously obtained the express permission of the owner.

Dialogs.Content: If you don't know, it's not for you to know.
I'm afraid if you don't have Master Kondyfa's permission, you won't be able to use our workshops. This doesn't prevent you from visiting them, of course.

Replies.Content: Where can I find Master Kondyfa?

Name: Architectroll's Lair
Description: Located on the edge of the underground lake, the lair of the Architectroll is a veritable caricature of a mining headquarters. Nonsensical diagrams are carved into the stone walls between bizarre handmade tools.

Name: Egrom of the Djinomarch
Description: About ten huts have been built around a totem pole representing a flaming reptilian creature. Visibly exhausted men and women try, as best they can, to take care of the huts' gardens. A surprisingly fat man supervises the workers.

Residents.Name: Cletus Fulamudd

Dialogs.Content: You'd be surprised. We're good fishermen and capable hunters. Plus, we often have visitors with whom we exchange essential goods. It's not an easy life, but we cope just fine.

Replies.Content: So do you have any interesting items to sell?

Dialogs.Content: For most of us, a few years.

Replies.Content: The region seems pretty unhospitable to me. How do you manage to survive?

Dialogs.Content:
A druid has already come to tell us about it.

Nonsense and poppycock!

What we like is running naked through the forests at night...

... oops, not again, my wife asked me stop telling people that.
A fish and seafood banquet is planned for the near future. Help the egrom by collecting fish along the shore.

You're free to visit our commercial centre. Hahaha!

* Cletus points to a hut that is indistinguishable from the others.

Indeed I do. The river to the south is full of tasty fish, and many lizards located in the arid plain are edible too.

I imagine you want to know about the most interesting local locations. It's always what people like you inquire about.

So, the small forest to the west of here is full of carnivorous plants. In the same direction you will find a cave housing some pretty aggressive trolls.

To the north, where the lands meet the ocean, you will find a wreck of a ship. Do not raise your hopes of finding lost treasures, mind, looters picked its hull clean years ago.

In the east, you run the risk of encountering a special kind of large predator. A nocturnal pygalalalus, I believe.
We are the Egrom of the Djinomarch. We live here in isolation waiting for the return of Djinomarch, Lord of the Desert Fairies.

Replies.Content: Ah! I've met people like you before.

Dialogs.Content:
Hello! Hello!

Come and rest a bit at Egrom du Djinomarque and please do not hesitate to share news from the rest of the world with us.

Replies.Content: Have you lived here for a long time?
You must know the area well.
Does your community need my aid?

Dialogs.Content: I'm not surprised, there are more and more of us these days. Clear proof that we have the truth!

Residents.Greets: Ho! Who do I see before me?

Name: Forest's Edge
Description: Although the individual trees are not particularly large, it is difficult to get inside the forest without adequate preparation.

Name: The Cliff of a Thousand Holes
Description: This sweeping cliff has been pierced over and over by subterranean creatures, creating an ominous honeycombed surface.

Dialogs.Content: *You approach the creatures.*
*This creature requires a building with the following characteristics:
*Something tells you that these worms are smarter than other creatures. Would it be possible to tame them?

Name: Unheroic Trash
Description: Certainly, the adventurers on this side of the Mists seem less concerned with nature than the Valsongeois. Vials, rusty blades, pieces of clothing, and all kinds of trinkets of the same ilk can be found along the trails through this forest.

Name: Cub meeting
Description: The hills of this part of the world seem much more alive than those of Valsonge. Even the grey of the rocky outcrops has a unique sheen. The winds also seem warmer and more intense than those you felt under the protective dome of the village.

Residents.Name: Cub
Residents.Greets: *Without care or concern for your presence, the wolf cub nibbles upon your lantern as if it were a particularly tasty bone.

Name: Gate of Justice
Description: A large, sturdy wooden gateway prevents caravans and travellers progressing too deep into Gantras without inspection. It's primary purpose is to limit the flow of contraband and smuggling, as well as making life more difficult for mercenary troops. To avoid scrutiny, outlaws instead opt for more treacherous mountain paths.

Dialogs.Content: Exactly. For we are an outpost for the great city of Giltanbourg! Its citizens' safety is our top priority. So, naturally, we monitor those who attempt to approach the city limits.

About Astridiel Valley, which separates you from the next checkpoint. You must cross it during the day unless you have a very well-armed escort or a death wish. 

At night, many creatures attack travellers. It's not yet known whether they came from the forest of Yesgomash to the east or down from the mountain of Arwell. The militia is able to contain these creatures in the valley, but we cannot protect nocturnal travellers. 

Anyway, only shady folk travel by night.
The Gate of Justice stands tall before you!

Yes. Well, I guess right now I'm the door that blocks your entry. Haha! Ahem... it is my solemn duty to verify who you are before you are permitted to enter Astridiel Valley. And also, to warn you about what you may find there.
*Holdo stares suspiciously at you as you leave.

Hurmm, yes, let's...

Who are you? Are you alone? Why are you approaching Gantras? Why do you have a strange accent and a strange lantern? What do you have in your bags? Why do you have this equipment? Who are your...

*After a few more questions, you begin to wonder if this is a joke.

So, are you going to answer me?

Name: Thormalek Academy
Description: Constructed primarily from  the wreckage of great sea vessels, Thormalek Academy casts its unusual shadow over a large section of the city. Dozens of students and teachers come in and out every hour, most of them locked in intellectual conversation.

Residents.Name: Gunya Karaken

Dialogs.Content:
The academy was named in honour of Malek Jon Thorval.

* Gunya watches you carefully, astutely noticing that you're going to need a more thorough explanation.

Jon Thorval was a title given to the captain of the captains, he who led the largest naval fleet before the seigneury officially joined Pireiria.

Symbolically, all the lords, well, counts now, still use the title of Jon Thorval. It's a way of respecting our naval tradition.

Replies.Content: So not all the counts are related to the Thorval family?

Dialogs.Content:
That's correct. In fact, our counts are usually from within the Kordan family, one of the old families of Pireiria. 

The Kordans, the Lightminds, and the Cessenesses are largely considered to be our country's oldest lineages. They're linked to the seigneuries of Ordval, namely Thorval, Wellnear, and Kortombe

The history of these great lineages bothers me somewhat, so I will not dwell on the subject.
Registration is closed for now, but if you want to visit the tower, you're free to do so. I can also answer your questions, of course, if you have any.

Replies.Content: What's the origin of the name Thormalek?

Dialogs.Content: Yes indeed! Our military mechanisms are mainly used on boats, but our researchers sometimes invent systems used by land soldiers and, of course, adventurers.
Gunya Karaken always needs a large amount of simple attachments for her students. She therefore organizes exchanges of minoris towards attachments of better quality.

As in all other academies, we of course teach the basic subjects for adolescents and adults. The education of the youngest takes place in another school.

However, we have built our reputation as one of the best institutions in the country on our jewellery, navigation, naval architecture, cartography, and military mechanics classes.

Residents.Greets: Hello and welcome to Thormalek Academy!

Name: Pringdan Hop Plantation
Description: Indubitably one of the largest agricultural lands in Thorval, the Pringdan Hop Plantation employs nearly 100 labourers. Most of them return to the mainland each evening, but dormitories have been built to accommodate the guards and other key workers.

Dialogs.Content:
We brew beer and liquor. To smugglers, thieves and drunks, it's like ants to honey. 

Plus, there are plenty of pirates who'd love to set up camp  on our island rather than having to take their ships to Thorbourg.
Welcome to the Pringdan Hop Plantation. You can visit at your leisure, but don't disturb the workers in the fields. They aren't paid enough to answer all of your questions.

Replies.Content: So I'll direct my questions to you then, I guess. Besides hops, do you grow other plants in the fields?
Why is there so much security around the hop fields?
Can you tell me about the island?

Dialogs.Content: [response to come]
I'm no agricultural specialist, but yes, we also grow barley, wheat, and a few other grains.

Name: Corinna Inn
Description:
A veritable fortress of an inn, the establishment is evidently well-maintained both inside and out. 

The main hall and the bedrooms are in exemplary condition. The specialized armaments of the militiamen indicate that the main threat of the place is not of human origin.

Residents.Name: Nallana Dyraenne

Dialogs.Content: Welcome to the safest and cleanest place on the Hammery Plain.

Yes, two particularly haughty members of the guilds of Ordval are causing me a headache. Whatever solution I take, I risk making enemies in one of the guilds.

And for an inn like mine, that wouldn't be a good thing.

Residents.Greets: Did you have a pleasant journey?

Dialogs.Content: Jullus is looking for information on the effectiveness of combat techniques against certain creatures. Maybe you can help him today?
Jullus would like to learn more about the creatures that hide in forests, mountains and swamps. Can you provide him with the information he so desires today?
I'm not just some measly doorman, I protect the inn from the monsters of the forest.

Yes, and it's not just those in the forest... the Golden Plateau to the south is also infested with strange creatures.

If you're not equipped for war, I advise you stay on the road and get to your destination without wandering.

Name: Stopover Square
Description: One of the oldest and most important public markets in the province of Ordval, Stopover Square sees thousands of sailors, traders and curious sightseers pass through each day. On occasion, you can even meet korkane and shandori travellers.

Residents.Name: Araki Miarki

Dialogs.Content:
* Araki frowns as if thinking at length about the meaning of your question.

Jawana is one of the three countries that signed the Treaty of Maliken. I thought everyone knew of it, but hey, I understand that historical politics does not interest everyone.

As for the shandoris, the natives of Jawana, you are speaking to one. Don't you dare call us mutants, hybrids, or worse, beast-men. I can only assure you that the morphology of my race is more complex and varied than that of humans like you.

* Araki gives a long sigh, and his gaze suddenly softens.

Please forgive me. Sometimes I tire of having to answer questions about my people. Though the ignorance of the many and the failings of education are not burdens that your shoulders alone should bear. The shandoris do not share their culture easily.
I can tell from your face that you haven't met many shandoris. That's normal, we rarely come so far from Jawana.

Residents.Greets: May the sun meet you each morning, and may the moon guard your dreams each night.

Dialogs.Content: By decree of Jon Thorval, a reward will be granted to all who assist in efforts to decrease the lion population around our great city.
A courier capable of crossing the Epirpon Pass is needed for a delivery of fresh hops from Dirontol. The cargo must be delivered to Mirousana Mill.

A ship belonging to one of the city's privateers has a machine capable of launching an assortment of spears. The authorities will therefore buy batches of sorontile spears for the bow, and spears of domane for the port and starboard sides.
The hop house requires tools for its work.
The number of caravan attacks in Prankster Hills has reached unacceptable levels. The authorities are offering a reward to anyone who helps reduce their numbers.
The shipyard is looking for large quantities of wood and metal for the construction of ships.
The Grandflood Shipyard needs tools for the construction of Jon Thorval's new fleet.
*You approach the bulletin board, which is packed full of requests, pleas, orders, and petitions...
The shipyard is looking for lots of wood and metal for the construction of its ships.

In that case, you will need to find a captain willing to take you aboard. Here, we deal with the exchange of goods. 

Visit the port, frequently, you'll find a willing captain soon enough.
You search, we provide!

Replies.Content: I'm looking for a boat to the islands.

Name: Academy of the Incredible Taran
Description: A towering thousand-year-old tree has been transformed into a tower of knowledge comprising a library, two classrooms and a laboratory. Animals stuffed in such a way  so as to give them human features are positioned in the various rooms of the academy. Incomprehensible pictures are drawn on the blackboards in every classroom. All the books are filled with obscure, occasionally lurid, scribbles.

Dialogs.Content: Hmmm. Is a poem written only in verse?

Replies.Content: No. Generally, the ink is in black. It could be written in a lounge or upside down. It could also be written in anger or in love.

Dialogs.Content: Lies!

Replies.Content: Okay. I'll take a bite of your bait. What can you tell me about Kochora?

Dialogs.Content:
It seems obvious to me.

* Taran looks at you with contempt.

Are you sane? You look sick to me.

* Taran's face suddenly softens.

I teach, that's what I do. I am the greatest teacher in all of Kochora.

* Taran's eyes again express his great surprise.

You really don't know anything!

* Excitement shines in Taran's eyes.

That's good, curiosity. It's a form of etalescence!

Replies.Content: Etalescence? I haven't come across that word.

Dialogs.Content: I saw you long before you were born.

Replies.Content: Can I take part in your lessons?

Dialogs.Content:
I expected you to answer that a poem could also be written in prose, but your answer pleases me too.

I'll have a second test for you later.
Are you a diviner?
No. Why?

Replies.Content: Didn't you say that you saw me before I was born?

Dialogs.Content:
* Taran's eyes widen in surprise.

The country in which we are in, of course.

Clearly, you have a lot to learn.

Replies.Content: This country is called Pireiria, and we are near the Duchy of Gantras.

Dialogs.Content: Protect your head!
Watch your feet!
Can you prove that I'm lying?

Replies.Content: I guess not, but I can be confident of its improbability.

Dialogs.Content: No... Yes... Are you dumber than a rock?
Ah! Another victory for Taran!

Replies.Content: I assume your name is Taran.

Name: East Gate of Giltanbourg
Description: The gate is closed and well-armoured guards are preventing anyone from passing.

Dialogs.Content: Welcome to Giltanbourg.
A smile, please?
Yes, you must be cleared at the south gate to enter the east gate.

Name: Entrance to Garrun'gol
Description: Between tents, coloured in the hues of the Arcanists Guild, there is globe of energy. The globe encompasses an entrance cut into the cliff of Garrun'gol.

Dialogs.Content: The number of creatures linked to the air element must be reduced in the caverns.
The number of creatures linked to the water element must be reduced in the caverns.
Your group has been chosen to study the nexus where the terrible elemental lord Xiryhaxi is located. No other Arcanists are allowed to approach until you secure the site.
It is requested that all Arcanists able to enter Garrun'gol Glacier collect samples there for the analysis team.
The flames of the fire barrier have diminished. The guild's scouts spotted a hellish being covered in flames moving into the centre of the barrier to reinforce it.
*You approach Morak's bulletin board which throbs with a faint magical resonance. Different magical texts reveal themselves according to the readers' elemental abilities...
The flames of the fire barrier have diminished. The guild scouts spotted a hellish being covered in flames placed in the centre of the barrier to reinforce it.
Your group has been chosen to study the nexus where the terrible elemental lord Elhoaxiry is located. No other Arcanists are allowed to approach until you secure the site.

Thanks to the reduction in the number of creatures from the Elemental Plane of Hydram, the Arcanists were able to advance closer to the ice barrier. There they discovered a most-troubling creature that now protects the barrier. Getting rid of it is of utmost priority for the guild.

Thanks to the reduction in the number of creatures from the Elemental Plane of Hydram, the Arcanists were able to advance closer to the ice barrier. There they discovered a most-troubling creature that now protects the barrier. Getting rid of it is of utmost priority for the guild.
It is requested that all Arcanists able to enter Garrun'gol Volcano collect samples there for the analysis team.
It is requested that all Arcanists able to enter Garrun'gol Cliff collect samples there for the analysis team.
The number of creatures linked to the fire element must be reduced in the caverns.

The influence of the Elemental Plane of Stratram has diminished in Garrun'gol. It is now possible to get closer to the wind barrier. Close enough indeed to see the terrible creature guarding the passage.

The influence of the Elemental Plane of Stratram has diminished in Garrun'gol. It is now possible to get closer to the wind barrier. Close enough indeed to see the terrible creature guarding the passage.
Your group has been chosen to study the nexus where the terrible elemental lord Glixiri is located. No other Arcanists are allowed to approach until you secure the site.

Yes, the elemental caverns of Garrun'gol have been known to Arcanists for a very long time, especially among the seekers in our elemental branch.

But because of the dangers present in the cave, we have never completed a full analysis.

I believe Garrun'gol is the key to accessing the power within the elemental pillar.

*Morak points you to a structure in the centre of the lake in the far west.
What is the element of the day?

Replies.Content: What can you tell me about the nexus?
Do you think the war is over?

Dialogs.Content:
I received a report on you that authorizes me to allow that.

And based on what the hydrothinkers have concluded, you're a great candidate for the dangerous experiment I'm currently running in Garrun'gol.

Replies.Content: What should I do to help?

Dialogs.Content:
The analysis team succeeded in isolating the orientation of the elemental polarization of the samples, they believe that the source of pyram comes from a precise point of the cave.

*It's difficult to comprehend, but it's very reminiscent of the Mists and rifts.

No, I do not think so. Elemental entities are not so easily defeated. There is a rapprochement between the elemental planes here. The lords will try to reopen their nexus.

I have no idea how long it will take them.

Replies.Content: But, I repelled the three entities...

Dialogs.Content:
You are in front of the elemental caverns of Garrun'gol. The energy flows of the three primary elements converge and concentrate in this place.

Which unfortunately causes problems...

Replies.Content: Alright, but what about this camp?

Dialogs.Content:
The nexus are points of connection between the elemental planes and our own. They are often kept open by elemental lords.

It is very interesting for us to have these nexus to study, but often it turns out that the danger they represent is too great. Still, the desire for wisdom lures us towards them.

Elemental lords are often conquerors, but in the case of Garrun'gol I wonder if it's some kind of... competition... between three elemental lords.

No place should have three elemental poles so close to one another.
You don't want to know, believe me...
It is too dangerous to send in beginner elementalists. First, complete your study on the dark feathers at the Arcane Tower.

Yes, so the currents of energy draw extraplanar creatures from the primary elemental regions of the nexus of the pillars of the great arch of the foundations of the fourth level of elemental entity materialization.

*Morak catches his breath.

You understand?

The analysis team succeeded in isolating the orientation of the elemental polarization of the samples, they believe that the source of hydram comes from a precise point in the cave.

*You can't help but draw parallels with the rifts in the Mists.

The analysis team succeeded in isolating the orientation of the elemental polarization of the samples, they believe that the stratram source comes from a precise point in the cave.

* The parallels between it and the Mists are striking.
I doubt that, but I have more important things to do than test your comprehension.

Yes. Though only because I see that you are a member of the guild. However, only Arcanists with a high enough rank are permitted to help me in my research. You...ah...you're going to need to fill out a simple waiver form.

Oh, so you're the one who smells like something is burning. Wait, what?! You defeated the fire terror?

I'll send my team of pyroprotectors to reduce the magical barrier. We will be able to see what is hidden behind it?

I dare not send our teams against the lords, but...

... you're not like the average Arcanist. I know magic well enough to have noticed that you have a way of facing or escaping death and then coming back as if nothing had happened. That lantern of yours seems tied to your abilities.

*Morak pauses before continuing.

For the moment, your secrets are of no interest to me. My priority is to end this elemental war. Too many Arcanists have been lost during this study of Garrun'gol.

I've created a unique bulletin board to help us organize these studies.

Depending on your elemental magic skills, new missions will be presented to you.
What happened to your hair? Ha! Ha! What a look! An old Arcanist saying claims it's always easy to recognize a Stratram Elementalist by the condition of their hair.
The dungeon is full of monsters...
You succeeded? That's wonderful. I'll send a team to destroy the remnants of the ice barrier.
Indeed you did. And since your third victory, things have calmed down somewhat. Elemental creatures still appear, but we haven't seen any terrors or lords in Garrun'gol.

A double utility...

We created an energy field to prevent creatures from leaving Garrun'gol. Directoflux generators are hidden amongst the tents.

The camp is also used to hide the cave from a bunch of pea-brained idiots from the Claw Assembly who decided to set up a giant tent a few hours' walk from such a dangerous locale.

Name: Sylph's Reflection
Description: A crystal encrusted with many strange symbols is chained to the floor of this room.

Dialogs.Content: ...the stone...a home...the power to set me free...your duty fulfilled...

... help...

*a form moves in the crystal, from facet to facet, to follow your movements. As if an entity is inside and watching you.

... who is here?...
... a presence?....

Name: The Clifftop Forge
Description: Amidst a small cluster of coal-blackened structures, a little building with a huge chimney is perched atop a cliff.

Dialogs.Content:
Forgagus offers you a daily challenge to produce and provide a weapon in exchange for one taken at random from his warehouse. 

Is it your lucky day?
*You approach Forgagus's bulletin board, which contains several smoke-stained requests for his apprentices

Larcen's captain of the guard would like a new mace, though a good portion of his budget has been squandered on booze. 

Use branzos for the head, feros for the guard. and chomne for the handle.
Watch out! Visitor in the forge!

Well... you!

I always warn my workers when those uninitiated with forge fires are around. Accidents happen!
Dev.Aventure
Dev.Aventure
Dev.Transport
Dev.Transport
Dev.Guide
Dev.Guide

Name: Golden Gin
Description: Founded at the beginning of the second century after the Treaty of Maliken, the Golden Gin has become a real institution in the barony of Kortombe. The reputation of luxurious alcohol, fruit, and sweets produced by the Arnoldus family extends to neighbouring seigneuries.

Dialogs.Content: Hrmph! I can hear your, Caroline!

You seem to me to be someone trustworthy. My son will soon be leaving for Maliken, but he must first go to the Duchy of Gantras.

A caravan will pick him up at the Kortombe border, but he must first get to the edge of Haularken Forest to reach the meeting point. He will therefore need to be escorted.

Can you accompany him?

Replies.Content: Sorry, I'm too busy to babysit right now. Perhaps later.
That sounds important, I'll leave immediately.

Dialogs.Content: And above all?
Yes? What do you want? I have too much work on to take care of curious tourists who couldn't tell a still from a stile. Come back in the evening and I might just have some time for you.

Replies.Content: Do you have any jobs for me? I could lighten your load.

Dialogs.Content: Blast! That would have really helped me out.
We have... gin! I know, what a surprise! If that's not your tipple, we also produce mead, cider, beer, cervoise, and wine.

Yes yes, I was getting to it!

We have one of the best stills in the region. So we also create potions and serums that help adventurers in their... well, adventures!

It is in fact an agricultural estate, we mainly produce cereals and fruits which can be used to make alcohol. We mostly use natural sugars, but we do import some from Thorval.

You can ignore Fabrice, he is a natural grump.
Right, okay. We'll hope that they will not cause too much damage to our plantations... and to our workers.

We always need field hands, but I imagine that's not what you're looking for.

I may have a job that's a little more your style. For days, vargrs have been prowling around the area. We're ready to pay you in coin if you rid us of their threat.

Normally, we would just hire local hunters, but one of these creatures is really more imposing and cunning than most. You seem resourceful to me, maybe there is something you can do.

Replies.Content: It sounds like a job for me.

Dialogs.Content: Hello! I am the master distiller of the Golden Gin. Do you want to taste one of my products?

Replies.Content: Do you have work for me?

Dialogs.Content: So much the better! After hearing it, you might change your ways and be a little more friendly. You're scaring all the customers away!

Name: Bear Territory
Description: A bear lives nearby.

Dialogs.Content: *This creature requires a building with the following characteristics:
*You approach the creature.*
*Taming a bear is quite a challenge. These beasts are intelligent but unpredictable.*

Name: Quell Bridge
Description:
Built from white stone, the Quell Bridge spans Sorcerer's River between Enchantress Park and the Ogres Path. An archer's tower was erected at the southwest end to defend the land surrounding Kortombourg.

Quell Vunkel was a young peasant from Arangfort who settled with his new fiance in Kortombe. He was greatly appreciated by all of Kortombourg, but following an attack by brigands, he lost both his memory and his sanity. Even in his madness, he made up his mind to protect Kortombourg from monsters that no one other than him saw. 

At the age of 45, he died trying to prevent robbers from crossing a stone jetty he had constructed. Relene Kortombe's father decided to build a bridge with a small guard post to honour Vunkel's bravery - the Quell Bridge.

Dialogs.Content: I am looking for a wife and a job. I hope you can help me find one...or the other...or both! By hiring me, you'd allow me to save enough for me to buy a house, which will allow me to found a family. What do you say?

Replies.Content: So are you ready to work for me?
I heard about your quest for work.

Dialogs.Content: Before working for you, friend, I need to make sure that you meet my requirements. Here they are:

Name: Passage of the Lithydrios
Description: A cable car traverses the river using huge mechanisms and a complex series of gears and pulleys. The system is operated by mechanical humanoids.

Name: Tunnel of the Caninbanes
Description: The tunnel leads to a small platform from which you can see the rest of the cave. A second tunnel goes in another direction.

Dialogs.Content: Introduction

Name: Alphonsine's Camp
Description: After a long day's adventuring, the small encampment before you would be a most welcome sight. Incense hangs in the air, mingling with the smell of brewing tea from a teapot heating on a small fire. A comfortable looking chair has been placed next to the campfire.

Dialogs.Content: You could pick me up some of the marnite rocks, located not far from my camp, while I rest. My health prevents me from working quickly, and I'd love to be back today.
